sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 12 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12, the alternating group A4, or the dihedral group D6.
message_1: Given a group G of order 12, prove that it is isomorphic to either C12, A4, or D6 by constructing a one-to-one and onto homomorphism from G to the specified group.
message_2:
To prove that a group G of order 12 is isomorphic to either C12, A4, or D6, we will use the Sylow theorems. Let's first find the Sylow subgroups of G.

By the Sylow theorems, the number of 3-Sylow subgroups, n_3, must divide the order of G (12) and be congruent to 1 mod 3. The possible values for n_3 are 1 and 4. Similarly, the number of 2-Sylow subgroups, n_2, must divide the order of G (12) and be congruent to 1 mod 2. The possible values for n_2 are 1 and 3.

Case 1: n_3 = 1 and n_2 = 1
If there is only one 3-Sylow subgroup and one 2-Sylow subgroup, then both are normal in G. Let P be the unique 3-Sylow subgroup and Q be the unique 2-Sylow subgroup. Since P and Q are normal, their direct product PQ is also normal in G. Moreover, since |P| = 3 and |Q| = 4, we have |PQ| = |P| * |Q| = 12, which is the order of G. Thus, G is isomorphic to the direct product of P and Q, which is isomorphic to C3 Ã— C4 = C12.

Case 2: n_3 = 4 and n_2 = 1
If there are four 3-Sylow subgroups and one 2-Sylow subgroup, let Q be the unique 2-Sylow subgroup. Since |Q| = 4, Q is isomorphic to either C4 or V4 (the Klein four-group). If Q is isomorphic to C4, then G has an element of order 4. However, A4 is the only group of order 12 with no element of order 4. Thus, G must be isomorphic to A4 in this case.

Case 3: n_3 = 1 and n_2 = 3
If there is only one 3-Sylow subgroup and three 2-Sylow subgroups, let P be the unique 3-Sylow subgroup. Since |P| = 3, P is isomorphic to C3. The group G acts on the set of left cosets of P by left multiplication. This action induces a homomorphism from G to the symmetric group S3. The kernel of this homomorphism is a normal subgroup of G contained in P. Since P is isomorphic to C3, its only normal subgroups are the trivial subgroup and itself. If the kernel is trivial, then the homomorphism is injective, and G is isomorphic to a subgroup of S3. However, this is not possible since |G| = 12 and |S3| = 6. Thus, the kernel must be P itself. The image of the homomorphism is a subgroup of S3 of order 4, which must be isomorphic to V4. Therefore, G is an extension of V4 by C3. The only such group of order 12 is D6, the dihedral group of order 12.

In conclusion, if G is a group of order 12, it must be isomorphic to either C12, A4, or D6.
